subject: Re: [junit] Re: Methods that does not return value
msgSnippet: Lily, As has been noted before on this thread, there are (pick your number, thousands is probably a gross understatement) Junit users that do not have VAJ at
messageBody:
Lily,

As has been noted before on this thread, there are
(pick your number, thousands is probably a gross
understatement) Junit users that do not have VAJ at
all and have little difficulty using Junit.

Perhaps you should post more details (stacktraces
even) about the failures you are seeing when
inVAJava() returns false as it does for all of us that
don't have/use VAJ.

However, I'll venture a suggestion that may make your
life better. When inVAJava() returns true, the UI
doesn't even give you a choice to use the reloading
class loader. Please make sure that the "Reload
classes every run" checkbox is *not* checked and see
if that makes things run correctly for you. Again,
I've only peeked at the code but it looks to me like
unchecking that option is what inVAJava() returning
true forces to be the case.

If the problem turns out to be the reloading class
loader, then I suggest you spend a little time
searching the Junit FAQ and the group archives because
the topic comes up a lot.

Rick

--- ok_lilya <lilya.jangirov@...> wrote:
> Rick,
>
> The reason why I want inVAJava() to return true, is
> so that
> JUnit will be able to run tests. (My own tests) When
> inVAJava()
> returns false or throws exception, the tests will
> not run.
>
> How do I know this? Well, I tried changing the
> inVAJava() method to
> return true and false.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Lily.
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Rick Berman
> <rick.berman@a...> wrote:
> > Throwing a class not found exception, catching it,
> and
> > then returning false is correct behavior for the
> > method inVAJava(). The class isn't found because
> you
> > aren't running inside of VAJ.
> >
> > You still haven't answered why you *want*
> inVAJava()
> > to return true when you aren't inside the VAJ
> > environment. Once we know that, then perhaps we
> can
> > get closer to addressing your issue.
> >
> > Rick
> >
> > --- ok_lilya <lilya.jangirov@r...> wrote:
> > > Rick,
> > >
> > > I tried leaving out
> com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport
> > > from classpath but
> > > then what happens, it throws a class not found
> > > exception and still
> > > doesn't return true.
> > >
> > > Thanks,
> > >
> > > Lily.
>
